column1: Plauen (German pronunciation: [ˈplaʊ̯ən]) is a town in the Free State of Saxony
column2: east-central Germany. It is the capital town of the district Vogtlandkreis. The town is situated near the border of Thuringia

column1: Plauen was founded by Polabian Slavs in the 12th century as "Plawe" and was passed to the Kingdom of Bohemia in 1327. The town was captured by the Archbishop of Magdeburg
column4: it was passed to Albertine Saxony and later in 1569 to the Electorate of Saxony. Plauen became incorporated into the Kingdom of Saxony in 1806 during the Napoleonic Wars.

column2: Plauen fell into the Soviet occupation zone of Germany
column3: which later became the German Democratic Republic (1949-1990). Plauen hosted a large Red Army occupation garrison and

The first mass demonstration against the communist regime in the GDR began in Plauen on 7 October 1989; this was the beginning of a series of mass demonstrations across the country and ultimately led to the re-unification of Germany in 1990.
